Title: Playful urban intervention as creative placemaking strategy in Jakarta
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Prawata, A.G., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper will discuss the interventions made by designers, artists and architects towards the urban and public spaces in Jakarta. Their urban interventions are intended to encourage creative activities, and playful experience amongst the citizens. The discussion will be based on the playful urban intervention activities during the Jakarta Architecture Triennale hosted by Indonesian Institute of Architects, Jakarta chapter. The interventions have the importance to be the urban fabrics that can create vibrant atmosphere to support the city, and they can be part of the creative sustainable city concept. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: city; creative; intervention; placemaking; urban; Architecture
References: Markusen, A., Gadwa, A., (2010) Creative Placemaking White Paper, , http://www.nea.gov/pub/CreativePlacemaking-Paper.pdf, [Online] [Accessed on 5th October 2019]; Prawata, A., Creative User Generated Urbanism (2015) Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences, 184, pp. 232-239; Staines, J., (2010) Sustainable Creative Cities, Role of Arts in Globalised Urban Context, , https://culture360.asef.org/magazine/sustainable-creative-cities-role-arts-globalised-urban-context/, [Online] [Accessed on 5th October 2019]; Landry, C., (2008) The Creative Cit A Toolkit for Urban Innovations; Courage, C., (2017) Creative Placemakings: A Typology of Placemaking Through the Prism of Arts Practices and Processes, , https://www.academia.edu/34583349/Creative_placemakings_a_typology_of_placemaking_through_the_prism-of-arts-practices-and-processes, [Online] [Accessed on 1st August 2019]; Courage, C., Moving beyond Creative Placemaking: The Micropublic of a Social Practice Placemaking Project (2015) University of Brighton, Association of American Geographers Annual Meeting

Title: Creative sustainability initiative for Jakarta's urban spaces
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Prawata, A.G., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper will discuss the creative initiative made by designer, architect, and contractor under the JKT Play movement and community towards the urban spaces in Jakarta. Their initiative is intended to encourage creative activities, and playful experience for the citizens, and as an alternative material to support sustainable architecture concept. The discussion will be based on the project's collaboration by designer, contractor, multinational company, food and beverages industry to create playful objects which can be used and explored by the communities. The initiative is based on the concern of the consumer waste, especially plastic cup, paper, and plastic bottle. The project has opened opportunities for creative industries, and designers to rethink and to approach the design methods and design exploration towards plastic wastes. It also can be a tool as an urban fabric or installation that can help creating colourful atmosphere for the city of Jakarta. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Bottles; Contractors; Plastic bottles; Plastic containers; Plastics; Alternative materials; creative; Creative industries; initiatives; Jakarta; Multi-national companies; Sustainable architecture; urban; Urban planning
References: Kwinter, S., (2013) Ecological Urbanism, p. 98; Chellaney, B., (2019) Pathways to Tackling the Plastic Waste Problem, , https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2019/05/14/commentary/world-commentary/pathways-tackling-plastic-waste-problem/#.XZ8nk2ZS-Uk, [Online] [Accessed on 10th October 2019]; Patel, P., Shah, A., Patel, H., Waste Plastic Bottles Offering Innovative Building Materials with Sustainable Application (2016) (2016) International Journal of Innovative and Emerging Research in Engineering (IJIERE), 3

Authors: Ardiani Y.M., Prawata A.G., Sholihin A.
Title: Application of biophilic architecture in apartment design
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ardiani, Y.M., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Prawata, A.G., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sholihin, A., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: According to UN Habitat related to Environmentally Sustainable, Healthy and Livable Human Settlements, an artificial environment has an impact on people's well-being, behavior and also on human health. At this time, Apartment design is a public space as a place for residents to socialize already lost, it was caused by the design itself. Even though an open space can be interacting and having ecological functions for the surrounding environment. The application of biophilic design in apartment is felt to be very necessary because it is able to help humans by providing a sense of comfort, calm and healing effect on a dwelling is needed. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: apartment; Artificial environments; biophilic; Ecological functions; Human health; Human settlements; Public space; Surrounding environment; Apartment houses
References: Aprilia, D.P., Sri, Y., Kusumaningdyah, N.H., APARTEMEN DENGAN PENDEKATAN DESAIN BIOPHILIK di JAKARTA SELATAN (2016) Arsitektur, 14; Arya, S.D.C., (2017) Pusat Kepedulian Dan Pelayanan HIV/Aids Dengan Pendekatan Biofilik di Jakarta Timur 8th Semester Students of Architecture in Binus University; Dan John Sons, W., (1976) Housing; Kellert, S., Calabrese, F., (2015) The PracTice Od Biophilic Design; Bright Green, T., (2015) 14 Patterns of Biophilic Oleh, Biophilic Design

Authors: Maldini B.A.M.S., Maldini M.S., Prawata A.G.
Title: Apartments with Organic Architecture Approach in Cilandak South Jakarta
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Maldini, B.A.M.S., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Maldini, M.S., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Prawata, A.G., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Jakarta as the capital city of Indonesia has a high rate density of population. The citycenter, Central Jakarta has been overpopulated. The increased density continues to spread across Jakarta. A new center of activity in South Jakarta is known as the Simatupang corridor, located in Cilandakneighborhoodwith its many office building, retails, and shopping center. Therefore, there are many domiciled employees moved into or near the area, especially Japanese expatriates. Designing an apartment building as a respond to its current issues, which are the high growing need for homes, limited land area, and poor environment qualities. The design of the apartment will be based on the theory of Organic Architecture. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: apartment; Cilandak; human settlement; organic architecture
Index Keywords: Architecture; Office buildings; apartment; Apartment buildings; Cilandak; Environment quality; High rate; Human settlements; Indonesia; Land areas; Apartment houses

Title: A study of brick facade design as preventive measure for passive cooling
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Prawata, A., Architecture Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: As the primary energy source of the earth, the sun, will also be the main aspect that need to be considered in architectural design. The sun will play a major part to create a good architecture, that would be part to create sustainable architecture. Buildings consume a lot of energy for cooling to achieve desirable thermal comfort conditions. In tropical climate, solar gain is resulting in high energy consumption, therefore the need and awareness to reduce building's energy is essential. One of the simple methods that can be used to prevent the high consumption of energy in buildings is by using natural and passive cooling systems. It uses non-mechanical techniques to maintain a comfortable indoor temperature. Shading is one of the passive design methods, which block the sun light before it hit the building surfaces. Shading reduces the solar radiation and it cools the building surface effectively, hence reducing the building energy performance significantly. This paper will discuss a study of bricks design facade that can be used to shade its own surfaces. The design configuration of the brick will provide self-shading system, that could help reduce the energy consumption in the buildings. © 2018 Institute of Physics Publishing. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy; Facade; Passive Design; Shading; Sustainable
Index Keywords: Brick; Cooling systems; Energy conservation; Energy utilization; Facades; Building energy performance; Energy; High energy consumption; Passive design; Primary energy source; Shading; Sustainable; Sustainable architecture; Architectural design

Title: Rethinking the architectural design concept in the digital culture (in architecture's practice perspective)
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Architecture Department, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No.9, Palmerah Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Prawata, A.G., Bina Nusantara University, Architecture Department, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No.9, Palmerah Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The architectural design stages in architectural practices or in architectural design studio consist of many aspects. One of them is during the early phases of the design process, where the architects or designers try to interpret the project brief into the design concept. This paper is a report of the procedure of digital tools in the early design process in an architectural practice in Jakarta. It targets principally the use of BIM and digital modeling to generate information and transform them into conceptual forms, which is not very common in Indonesian architectural practices. Traditionally, the project brief is transformed into conceptual forms by using sketches, drawings, and physical model. The new method using digital tools shows that it is possible to do the same thing during the initial stage of the design process to create early architectural design forms. Architect's traditional tools and methods begin to be replaced effectively by digital tools, which would drive bigger opportunities for innovation. © 2017 Author(s).
References: (2013) RIBA Plan of Work 2013, , RIBA, ISBN: 978-1 85946 5196; Asanowicz, A., (2002) Sixth Design and Decision Support Systems in Architecture and Urban Planning - Part One: Architecture Proceedings Edited by Timmermans, pp. 35-37. , Harry (Avegoor, The Netherlands); Asanowicz, A., (2012) Digital Aids to Design Creativity, 2, pp. 263-270. , eCAADe 30.2; Cannaerts, C., (2009) Proceedings of the Design Modelling Symposium (Berlin); Dorta, T., (2005) Digital Design: The Quest for New Paradigms, 23 ECAADe Conference Proceedings, pp. 819-827. , ISBN: 0-9541183-3-2 (Technical University of Lisbon, Lisbon)
Correspondence Address: Prawata, A.G.; Bina Nusantara University, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No.9, Indonesia; email: albertus_prawata@binus.ac.id
Conference name: 3rd International Conference on Construction and Building Engineering: Smart Construction Towards Global Challenges, ICONBUILD 2017

Title: The creative movement of ‘park(ing) day’ in Jakarta
Source title: Advances in Civil Engineering and Building Materials IV - Selected and Peer Reviewed Papers from the 2014 4th International Conference on Civil Engineering and Building Materials, CEBM 2014
Authors with affiliations: Prawata, A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The government has a strong role in making plans and shaping the city. The planning establishment of the government is based on capital-intensive strategic actions, so they can shape the urban spaces according to a certain set of values. These values are clearly made in the patterns of resource consumption. However, they often create a hierarchical gap between the people and the communities. In the city, the economy becomes the basis of how the urban spaces are shaped and created. New economic activities often have an impact of degrading the quality of the spaces. As a result, the city will lose its attractions, they become aesthetically unpleasant, and people feel alienated. The purpose of this paper is to discuss the interaction and appreciation of creative users and the citizens of the city towards urban spaces, and how this will encourage endless collaboration amongst local citizens to create thoughtful and meaningful designs for the public. The discussion and arguments will be based on some creative movements such as ‘Park(ing) Day.’ It has the importance to be a city icon and become an urban fabric that supports the city, becoming a part of the sustainable city concept. The engagement and ideas from the creative user can be a strong foundation for creative urbanism that has the power to re-shape the city spaces to be more liveable. Therefore, it can also bring a new identity and vibrant atmosphere to a certain area as well as to the city. © 2015 Taylor & Francis Group, London.
Author Keywords: Creative; Creative user; Park(ing) day; Urban spaces
Index Keywords: Building materials; Economics; Regional planning; Creative; Creative user; Economic activities; Government IS; Resource consumption; Sustainable cities; Urban fabrics; Urban spaces; Urban planning
